title: UK attorney general lambasts ‘dead parliament’
text:
UK Attorney General Geoffrey Cox | Leon Neal/Getty Images UK attorney general lambasts ‘dead parliament’ Geoffrey Cox defends his advice that suspending parliament was legal, saying the government acted ‘in good faith.’

The U.K. attorney general chastised what he called “a dead parliament” during a robust defense of his advice to ministers that suspending parliament was legal.

The U.K. government “acted in good faith” when it suspended parliament on the grounds it was necessary to push for a new domestic legislating agenda, Geoffrey Cox told MPs before taunting them that they are “too cowardly” to vote no confidence in the government.

“This parliament is a dead parliament. It should no longer sit. This parliament is a disgrace,” he said, “Since I am asked, they could vote no confidence at any time. But they are too cowardly to give it a go.”

“This parliament should have the courage to face the electorate. But it won’t. It won’t, because so many of them are really all about preventing us leaving the European Union. But the time is coming when even these turkeys won’t be able to prevent Christmas,” he said.

Responding this morning to an urgent question from Scottish National Party’s MP Joanna Cherry, Cox said his advice to the government had been sound at the time. “At all times the government acted in good faith and in the belief that its approach was both lawful and constitutional,” he said.

Parliament resumed business today after judges at the Supreme Court ruled Tuesday that Prime Minister Boris Johnson’s advice to the queen to suspend parliament for five weeks was “unlawful.”

"The time is coming when even these turkeys won’t be able to prevent Christmas" — U.K. Attorney General Geoffrey Cox

Cox rebuffed calls for him to step down, saying: “If every time I lost a case I was called upon to resign, I would probably have never had a practice.”

“These are complex matters on which senior and distinguished lawyers will disagree,” he added.

Cox added he would consider in the coming days whether the government should disclose more information about the advice he gave in this case.

Former Tory MP Oliver Letwin, who now sits as an independent, challenged Cox to guarantee that the government would not suspend parliament again — apart from perhaps a few days in the run-up to a queen’s speech.

Cox avoided a straight answer, only saying “there will be no prorogation that doesn't comply with the terms of the judgment of the Supreme Court.”
description: Geoffrey Cox defends his advice that suspending parliament was legal, saying the government acted ‘in good faith.’
